ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: As a student in global history, I was not aware of many of the debates animating the course. I was very happy to learn them and gain knowledge of the stakes in environmental history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The assigned reading were interesting and very balanced. Professor Coen is an excellent seminar leader and ensured that our discussion remained on point. The course could benefit from a few bridge texts/background reading given the varying backgrounds of the group.

I was exposed to several new authors and learned more about the historiography of science and imperialism. I particularly enjoyed when we were able to connect and contrast readings from different weeks. However, I did not feel the course was as coherent as I would have liked. A reading course such as this is likely to be somewhat idiosyncratic, but I would still have preferred more of an arc to the course as a whole.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. For students interested in histories of knowledge, ideas and environment as well as about the comparative history of empires, this could be very useful course.
